Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geometric Shape Error Control for High-Precision Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to establish methodologies for error prediction and control of geometric shapes associated with a wide range of additive manufacturing (AM) processes. The ultimate goal is to overcome a major barrier of direct digital manufacturing: inadequate dimensional accuracy in current AM processes. The proposed research strategy is to establish a methodological framework for system-level, smart, and high precision shape error compensation and control. The research plan consists of four research tasks: (1) modeling and prediction of profile deviations for complex shapes; (2) efficient experimental designs and analysis strategies for modeling profile deviations; (3) optimal compensation and smart shape-to-shape control of profile deviations, and (4) experimental investigation and validation.

Successful completion of the project is expected to significantly improve the geometric accuracy of AM-built products. The research will produce new knowledge regarding system-level or universal geometric shape accuracy control methodologies to reduce duplicated efforts for wider and quicker adoption of AM technologies, and high-precision and smart shape-to-shape compensation methodologies to avoid post-processing and extensive process calibration efforts prior to production. The research outcomes including patents will facilitate wider and quicker adoption of AM technology, spurring manufacturing innovations and job creation. The research project will provide new curriculum on AM technology and manufacturing education. Inter-university workshops and video conferences involving faculty and graduate students have been and will continue to be organized for synergistic collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this research project is to establish methodologies for error prediction and control of geometric shapes associated with a wide range of additive manufacturing (AM) processes.  

Although AM or 3D printing holds great promise as a direct manufacturing technology, the geometric accuracy of AM built products remains a critical issue, especially for freeform products with complex geometric shapes.  The existing quality engineering concepts and methods have been rooted in mass production paradigm, while AM represents a paradigm shift to mass customization. One major challenge of establishing the new quality control methodologies for AM is how to learn from geometry shape data with limited training samples in the one-of-kind manufacturing environments. 

This research project establishes a set of methodologies to predict and compensate planar shape deviations of AM built freeform products based on a limited number of simple trial shapes.  The geometric shapes include planar freeform shapes built horizontally and vertically. Experimental investigation and validation have been conducted in the stereolithography process, fused deposition modeling process, and laser powder bed fusion process. The research outcomes demonstrate the prospect of proactively improving printing accuracy of arbitrary planar products built by a varieties of AM processes. The methodologies have been reported in journal and conference publications. One US patent has been published on predicting and compensating in-plane freeform shape deviations.  

 

This project provides interdisciplinary training opportunities for graduate students and contributes to the training of new workforce with expertise in quality engineers and process analytics for additive manufacturing. Two PhD students have graduated and pursued a career in additive manufacturing. One more PhD student will graduate by December 2018.  New curricular materials have been developed for teaching. 

 

This project enhances research collaborations involving not only top domestic universities, but also international institutions in Italy, France, and Hong Kong. AM research workshops have been organized regularly to promote 3D printing accuracy control research. Other than publications and conference presentations, research blog has been established for broad dissemination. Academia-Industry liaison has been initiated for both research collaborations and workforce training.


Last Modified: 09/29/2018
Modified by: Qiang Huang
